identified-content.classifier: Workfare and Employment of Welfare Recipients

abstract.p: Joseph H Ross letter on July 11 editorial says welfare to work programs provide little training and no support after employment, elements needed for long-term positive results

block.p: I read your July 11 editorial ''Diminishing the Welfare Rolls'' with great concern.
I read your July 11 editorial ''Diminishing the Welfare Rolls'' with great concern.

Before we trumpet the achievements of welfare-to-work programs, I urge New Yorkers to consider the effect they have on people's lives. We need to look at the jobs people secured, the pay and benefits, and whether these jobs have moved anyone out of poverty. Finally, we need to consider how changes in our economy will affect those least prepared for a downturn.

As director of Partnership for the Homeless's job training program, I know that ''welfare to work'' provides little training -- particularly in crucial ''soft skills'' -- and no support after employment. Without these components, ''welfare to work'' may provide short-term success stories, but will offer few long-term positive results.
JOSEPH H. ROSS New York, July 11, 2000
